moves.1. e4 c5: My usual play as black, the Sicilian
moves.2. d4: At this point, I assumed the morra gambit...
moves.2... cxd4 3. Qxd4: I disagree with this move only because it allows black to gain tempo...
moves.3... Nc6 4. Qd1: A really passive retreat by white makes Qxd4 look a bit silly.
moves.4... Nf6 5. Nc3 g6: planning a sort of dragon variation here with a bishop on g7
moves.6. Nd5: White hangs the pawn on e4. I looked hard and tried to remember any traps here, but couldn't find one
moves.7. Bf4: An obvious and easily defended threat of Nc7+, but good development of the bishop. At this point, I was sort of eyeing Qa5+. If it weren't for the defence of the white queen, it wins some material.
moves.7... e5: Defending Nc7+ and attacking the bishop
moves.8. Bd3: Bd3?? Blunder number 1. Loses a Bishop. Now that white has cut off the defence of the knight on d5...
moves.11. Qd2 Bg7: Threatening Bxc3 to win the queen...
moves.13. Ke2 Nd4+: Thought about taking the rook, but I figured It get the knight closer to the action first.
moves.14. Ke3: Ke3?? Pins the bishop on d3 and loses a queen for a bishop. Do you see it?
moves.15. Qxh6 Nf5+: With the bishop on d3 pinned, Nf5+ wins. White resigned here.
